Title.evidence: This multicentre pilot study investigated the role of peroperative carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)‐specific fluorescence imaging during cytoreductive surgery–hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy surgery in peritoneal metastasized colorectal cancer.

Intervention.evidence: The use of SGM‐101 in patients with peritoneally metastasized colorectal carcinoma is feasible, and allows intraoperative detection of tumour deposits and alteration of the PCI.

Objective.evidence: This multicentre pilot study investigated the role of peroperative carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)‐specific fluorescence imaging during cytoreductive surgery–hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy surgery in peritoneal metastasized colorectal cancer.

Number_Analysed.evidence: A correct change in peritoneal carcinomatosis index (PCI) owing to fluorescence imaging was seen in four of the 14 included patients.

Result_Outcome.evidence: A correct change in peritoneal carcinomatosis index (PCI) owing to fluorescence imaging was seen in four of the 14 included patients.
